raw_text:
US actor Ossie Davis found dead
 
 US actor Ossie Davis has been found dead at the age of 87.
 
 Davis, who was married to actress Ruby Dee, was found dead on Friday in his hotel room in Miami Beach, Florida, where he was making a film. Davis, whose 65-year career included credits as a producer, director, actor and writer for stage and screen, was also a civil rights activist. Miami Beach police spokesman Bobby Hernandez said the cause of death appeared to be natural.
 
 Davis's body was discovered by his grandson and paramedics at the Shore Club hotel in Miami Beach, where the actor had been shooting the film Retirement. Mr Hernandez said: "After gaining entry, they found Mr Davis had passed away. "The cause of death appears to be natural. According to his grandson he was suffering from heart disease." Some of Davis's best known roles included The Joe Louis Story and Gone Are the Days - a film he adapted from his own play, Purlie Victorious. He also appeared in 7 Spike Lee movies, including School Daze, Do the Right Thing and Jungle Fever.
 
 His film debut, in 1950, was in the film No Way Out, starring Sydney Poitier and Ruby Dee. Davis and Dee were married for more than 56 years and together received Kennedy Center honours in 2004 for their body of work. The Actors' Equity Association issued a statement calling Davis "an icon in the American theatre" and he and Dee "American treasures". Davis was also a prominent figure in the civil rights movement and was a voice for racial equality. He was a featured speaker at the funerals of both Martin Luther King Jnr and Malcolm X. Besides Dee, Davis is survived by three children Nora, Hasna and Guy, a blues artist, and seven grandchildren.
llama3.2:1b: Ossie Davis, 87, US actor found dead in Miami Beach hotel room; cause appears to be natural death from heart disease; married to actress Ruby Dee for over 56 years; worked in film, stage, and TV, including notable roles in The Joe Louis Story and Gone Are the Days; received Kennedy Center honors for his body of work.

His death appears natural due to heart disease; his legacy includes appearances in Spike Lee's films such as School Daze and Jungle Fever. opencoder:1.5b:
US actor Ossie Davis has been found dead at the age of 87, with her death following the shooting in Miami Beach that occurred Friday.

Davis, who was married to actress Ruby Dee, was a natural killer who committed suicide in a hotel room. The cause of death seemed to be natural and consistent with personal experiences. According to his family, he suffered from heart disease, though this is less common. His film debut, No Way Out, was based on his work and stars Sydney Poitier and Ruby Dee. Davis and Dee are married for over 56 years, and they receive Kennedy Center honors, a voice for racial equality, and were featured speakers at funerals of Martin Luther King Jr and Malcolm X.

Davis' best roles include The Joe Louis Story and Gone Are the Days - a film adaptation from his own play, Purlie Victorious. He also appeared in 7 Spike Lee movies and School Daze, Do the Right Thing, and Jungle Fever. He was also featured on stage at events like the Pride and Prejudice show and the CBS Kids channel program.

His son Nora, Hasna, helped him heal from heart disease, and has been a significant contributor to the civil rights movement and the American film industry's preservation of artistic freedom. His grandson Guy, a blues artist, has also contributed to this cause.
smollm:1.7b:
US actor Ossie Davis found dead in hotel room in Miami Beach, Florida, where he was making film. US actor Ossie Davis has been found dead at the age of 87. Davis, who was married to actress Ruby Dee, was found dead on Friday in his hotel room in Miami Beach, Florida, where he was making a film. Davis, whose 65-year career included credits as a producer, director, actor and writer for stage and screen, was also a civil rights activist.

Davis's body was discovered by his grandson and paramedics at the Shore Club hotel in Miami Beach, where the actor had been shooting the film Retirement. Davis said: "After gaining entry, they found Mr Davis had passed away. The cause of death appears to be natural." Some of Davis's best known roles included the film Joe Louis Story and Gone Are the Days - a film he adapted from his own play, Purlie Victorious. He also appeared in 7 Spike Lee movies, including School Daze, Do the Right Thing and Jungle Fever.

Davis was born on June 29, 1924, in New Orleans, Louisiana, to James Davis and Ruby Dee. He grew up in a poor household with his parents and siblings. Davis's father died when he was just two years old, and his mother remarried soon after. Davis attended the New Orleans public schools and later moved to New York City for further education.

Davis graduated from the New York City College of Technology (now known as City University of New York) in 1947 with a degree in drama. He then went on to study acting at the American Theatre Workshop, where he was mentored by Lee Strasberg. Davis's early career included roles in films such as The Big Broadcast and The Big Broadcast II.

In 1950, Davis made his film debut in No Way Out, a comedy starring Sidney Poitier and Ruby Dee. He also appeared in several other Spike Lee films during the 1950s, including School Daze (1952), Do the Right Thing (1953) and Jungle Fever (1954). Davis's film debut was followed by a string of successful roles in the 1960s, including in the television series The Jack Benny Program.

Davis's body was found on Friday in his hotel room in Miami Beach, Florida, where he was making a film. Davis's cause of death appears to be natural and there is no explanation for the sudden death. Davis was survived by his wife Ruby Dee, who had been his partner in life and cinema, as well as seven children: Nora, Hasna, Guy, Tina, Tiffany, Amber and Lillian.

Davis's legacy extends beyond his film career. He was a prominent figure in the civil rights movement and was an outspoken advocate for racial equality throughout his life. Davis was also a vocal critic of racism and discrimination, and he spoke out against injustice and inequality whenever he could.

In 2004, Davis was awarded the Kennedy Center Honors for his contributions to American theatre. He was also inducted into the American Theatre Hall of Fame in 1985. Davis's body is currently being held at the New Orleans morgue, where it will be identified and reburied with full military honors.
